title: Solomon's Prayer of Dedication
shortSummary: In 2 Chronicles 6, Solomon offers a heartfelt prayer of dedication for the newly built temple, acknowledging God's promises to David and petitioning God to hear the prayers of His people. This chapter highlights God's holiness, the significance of the temple as His dwelling place, and the conditions for God's blessing upon Israel.
timeline: c. 970 BC - Solomon's reign and the dedication of the temple in Jerusalem

keyCharacters.name: Solomon
keyCharacters.description: King of Israel who built the temple and offers the dedicatory prayer, affirming God's promises and seeking His presence.

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: Solomon's father, the former king who desired to build the temple but was told by God that Solomon would build it instead.

keyCharacters.name: The Congregation of Israel
keyCharacters.description: The assembled people of Israel who stand and witness Solomon's prayer, representing the nation before God.

definitions.definition: A biblical expression describing God's mysterious and majestic presence, often associated with His holiness and transcendence.
The sacred chest containing the tablets of the Ten Commandments, symbolizing God's covenant and presence with Israel.
A humble and earnest prayer or request made to God, often in times of need or distress.
A platform made of bronze on which Solomon stood to pray during the temple dedication ceremony.

outline.heading: Solomon's Acknowledgment of God's Presence and Promise
outline.description: Solomon recalls God's promise to David that He would dwell with His people and affirms that he has fulfilled David's desire by building the temple as a permanent dwelling for God.

outline.heading: Solomon's Prayer of Blessing and Praise
outline.description: Solomon blesses the congregation and praises God for His faithfulness in keeping His covenant with David, acknowledging God's mercy and covenantal faithfulness.

outline.heading: Petition for God's Presence and Hearing Prayers
outline.description: Solomon prays for God's continued presence in the temple, asking that God hear the prayers made toward this holy place and forgive the people when they repent.

outline.heading: Conditions for God's Forgiveness and Blessing
outline.description: Solomon outlines various situations—sin, drought, pestilence, captivity—and prays that God will hear and forgive His people when they repent and pray toward the temple.

outline.heading: Inclusion of Strangers and Warfare in Prayer
outline.description: Solomon extends the prayer to include foreigners who come to worship God and petitions for God's help and forgiveness during times of war and exile.

outline.heading: Final Petition for God's Favor and Blessing
outline.description: Solomon concludes by asking God to arise into His resting place, bless His priests and people, and remember the mercies promised to David.

application: Trust in God's faithfulness to keep His promises as Solomon did, especially regarding His covenant and presence.
Approach God with humility and earnest prayer, knowing He hears those who sincerely seek Him toward His appointed place.
Confess sin promptly and turn to God in repentance, trusting in His readiness to forgive and restore.
Include others in your prayers, remembering that God's mercy extends to all who come to Him in faith.

keyVerses.text: O LORD God of Israel, there is no God like thee in the heaven, nor in the earth; which keepest covenant, and shewest mercy unto thy servants, that walk before thee with all their hearts:
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes God's uniqueness, covenant faithfulness, and mercy toward those who wholeheartedly follow Him.

keyVerses.text: But will God in very deed dwell with men on the earth? behold, heaven and the heaven of heavens cannot contain thee; how much less this house which I have built!
keyVerses.significance: Solomon humbly acknowledges God's transcendence and the temple's limited capacity to contain His infinite presence.

keyVerses.text: Hearken therefore unto the supplications of thy servant, and of thy people Israel, which they shall make toward this place: hear thou from thy dwelling place, even from heaven; and when thou hearest, forgive.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the importance of prayer directed toward God's chosen place and His readiness to forgive upon hearing.

keyVerses.text: Now, my God, let, I beseech thee, thine eyes be open, and let thine ears be attent unto the prayer that is made in this place.
keyVerses.significance: Solomon's final plea underscores the need for God's attentive presence and responsiveness to the prayers of His people.
